subject: Re: Pluggable Selector considered harmful? (Re: [junit] Re: Observations from a production use of JUnit4)
msgSnippet: ... I understand this concern and it bothers me, too. In the case of discovering rule methods from a single class, however, it seems the potential damage is
messageBody:
Kent Beck wrote:

> When I was looking at lots of Smalltalk code that used Pluggable Selector
> the consequence I found most annoying was that I could not delete
> seemingly-unreferenced methods because they might be invoked dynamically.

I understand this concern and it bothers me, too. In the case of
discovering rule methods from a single class, however, it seems the
potential damage is limited. Also, the naming convention makes the code
self-documenting to a strong degree.

Example.

public class StopProduction {
public boolean canStopBuilding(Product product) {
return new ShortCircuitRuleset(this).evaluate(product);
}

public boolean ruleHasNotBeenSold(Product product) {
return product.getSalesOrder() == null;
}

public boolean ruleHasNotGoneTooFarAlongProductionLine(
Product product) {

return product.getLocationInProductionLine()
< ProductionLine.station(200);
}

public boolean ruleHasNotBeenConfigured(Product product) {
return !product.getConfiguration().isComplete();
}
}

Here, ShortCircuitRuleset discovers all boolean methods whose name
starts with "rule". It then uses reflection to invoke each method
passing in the parameters it received in evaluate(). If any method
returns false, the ruleset "short circuits" and returns false; otherwise
it returns true.

What does it take to know that the rule*() methods are likely invoked by
reflection? Knowledge of the basic design of ShortCircuitRuleset and
searching for any ShortCircuitRuleset instance that refers to an
instance of the current class.

Is that too much? I don't know. I know that Pluggable Selector gone mad
is annoying like any other pattern gone mad. I just didn't think I'd
gone mad, so I'm trying to understand why people think I did. :)

Thanks for your feedback.
